summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting an interview with a witness, referred to as [WITNESS], conducted in Stockholm, Sweden on February 5, 2020. The witness provides detailed information about interactions with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, including recruitment attempts targeting the witness's daughter, financial offers, and travel. The witness also discusses perceptions of Epstein's social circle and her eventual decision to cut off contact.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the investigation. The witness describes him as a 'godfather figure' who, with Ghislaine Maxwell, attempted to recruit the witness's daughter, offered to pay for her education, and invited her to travel and live with them.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Actively involved with Epstein in contacting the witness and her daughter. Described by the witness as 'a wolf' who 'picks the girls,' and who presented herself as a 'big sister' or mother-like figure to facilitate access.

persons.name: [WITNESS]
persons.context: The individual being interviewed. She is the mother of a girl (her daughter) whom Epstein and Maxwell repeatedly attempted to recruit. She details their methods, her initial trust, and her eventual decision to cut off contact and warn others.

persons.name: [WITNESS'S DAUGHTER]
persons.context: The daughter of the witness. Epstein and Maxwell repeatedly attempted to have her move in with them, travel with them, and attend Juilliard, with Epstein offering to pay. The witness states her daughter does not discuss the case.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned by the witness as one of the famous people who visited Epstein's house in Palm Beach, which contributed to her initial perception that Epstein was not a criminal.

persons.name: Prince
persons.context: Mentioned by the witness as one of the famous people (likely Prince Andrew) who visited Epstein's house in Palm Beach.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Present for the witness interview in Stockholm, indicating the interview was part of a U.S. criminal investigation.

persons.name: FBI Special Agent
persons.context: Present for and presumably conducting the witness interview in Stockholm.

persons.name: Swedish Police Detective Inspector
persons.context: Two Swedish police officials were present for the interview conducted in Stockholm.

persons.name: NYPD Detective
persons.context: Mentioned as being present for the interview, indicating inter-agency cooperation.

persons.name: Driver
persons.context: An older, polite man who would pick up the witness's daughter from her home to bring her to Epstein's house. He reassured her about safety when traveling to New Mexico.

persons.name: Housekeeper
persons.context: Would answer the phone at Epstein's house and reassure the witness that everything was okay when she called to check on her daughter.

persons.name: British Journalist
persons.context: Contacted the witness approximately seven years prior to the interview, leading her to move to get away from the inquiries.

persons.name: Lawyer
persons.context: The witness called Epstein's office after moving to New York and spoke with his lawyer, instructing him to tell Epstein not to contact her daughter anymore and threatening a lawsuit.

connections.description: Worked together to recruit the witness's daughter, with Maxwell acting as the primary contact and facilitator while Epstein provided financial incentives and the overall direction.
Maxwell repeatedly contacted the daughter and her mother, presenting herself as a 'big sister' or mother-like figure, offering educational support and travel to gain trust and access.
Epstein was presented as a 'godfather figure,' offered to pay for Juilliard, and directly asked the daughter to travel and live with him and Maxwell.
Had repeated phone and in-person contact over several years regarding her daughter. The witness initially trusted Maxwell but later came to distrust and blame her.
The witness states Trump visited Epstein's house in Palm Beach, which she cites as a reason she initially believed Epstein was not a criminal.
The witness states a prince visited Epstein's house in Palm Beach, contributing to her perception of his legitimacy.
Maxwell would have a driver pick up the witness's daughter from her home to bring her to Epstein's house.

events.title: Initial Contact by Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell first contacted the witness, asking about her daughter and stating she wanted to take the daughter under her wing.

events.title: Travel to New Mexico
events.description: The witness's daughter, then about 15 years old, traveled with Epstein and Maxwell on his private jet from West Palm Beach to New Mexico for a weekend after initial refusals.

events.title: Move to New York
events.description: The witness and her daughter moved from West Palm Beach to New York in the summer of 1997. Shortly after, the witness called Epstein's lawyer to demand no further contact with her daughter.

events.title: Warning at a Party
events.description: At a party, the witness overheard a young woman planning to meet Epstein and warned her not to go.

events.title: FBI Interview in Stockholm
events.description: The witness was interviewed by the FBI, AUSA, and Swedish police in Stockholm, Sweden, providing detailed allegations about Epstein and Maxwell's recruitment tactics.

keyFacts: The witness describes a coordinated effort by Epstein and Maxwell to recruit her daughter, using offers of paid education at Juilliard, travel, and a place to live as incentives.

The witness states that seeing famous people like Donald Trump and a prince at Epstein's house initially made her believe he could not be a criminal, indicating how Epstein used his social connections to create a facade of legitimacy.
The witness characterizes Ghislaine Maxwell as 'a wolf' who 'picks the girls,' placing primary blame on her for the recruitment of young women.
The witness is willing to testify in New York if charges are brought against Ghislaine Maxwell.
The document reveals the use of staff (driver, housekeeper) to facilitate contact with and transport of the targeted girl, and to reassure concerned parents.
